• According to the U.S. Census and HUD CHAS data, over 50% of Hattiesburg renters are housing cost-
burdened, spending more than 30% of their income on rent.

• Roughly 1 in 4 renters are severely burdened, paying over 50% of income.
• The average monthly rent in Hattiesburg increased by nearly 18% between 2021 and 2024, outpacing local
wage growth.
• Housing availability for low- to moderate-income households remains constrained.
• As of 2024, there are fewer than 35 publicly subsidized units available per 100 extremely low-income
households in the Hattiesburg metro area.
• The Hattiesburg Housing Authority waitlist remains closed due to overwhelming demand, with hundreds of
eligible households unable to access rental assistance or housing vouchers.
2. Strategic Infill Opportunity

• The 32.88-acre project site sits in Ward 2, a historically underserved district with large tracts of flood-
prone, underutilized public and semi-public land.

• Rather than pursuing greenfield expansion that strains city services, Eagles Flock to Woodstock leverages
flood-adapted construction to redevelop land already within city limits, reducing sprawl while increasing
housing supply.
• Because the site is adjacent to existing sewer, power, and water infrastructure, per-unit infrastructure cost is
substantially lower than new exurban development—yielding both short-term savings and long-term
serviceability.
3. Alignment with Local and Regional Goals
• The City of Hattiesburg’s Comprehensive Plan 2040 calls for:
o Expansion of affordable housing options
o Redevelopment of underused floodplain parcels
o Promotion of walkable, mixed-use neighborhoods near the Leaf River corridor
